TEXT:
Patient seen an examined with MICU team.  I agree with their assessment
   and plan of care.
   Chief Complaint:  Hypoxemia x 2 days
   HPI:
   Briefly 80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, gastroparesis, Stage IV sarcoidosis,
   and poorly controlled COPD.  She has a 2 year history of multiple
   abdominal surgeries: initially a sigmoid resection for large bowel
   obstruction c/b anastomotic leak and multiple episodes of
   intra-abdominal abscesses requiring surgical correction and revision,
   diverticulitis with colovesicular fistula in [**2169**] that required partial
   colonic resection and an ileostomy. In [**2170-12-4**], she had the ileostomy
   reversed and since then, she has had worsening of her diarrhea.
   Since [**Month (only) **], she has been admitted to OSH 5 times for long hospital stays
   with extensive work up that has been negative so far. Most recently,
   she was admitted to OSH [**3-27**] where workup again has been negative. She
   has been getting IVF; lasix held. The family requested a transfer to
   [**Hospital1 19**] this for a 2nd opinion at a [**Hospital 7454**] care center for her GI
   symptoms.  Two hours prior to transfer she developed gradually
   worsening dyspnea and an oxygen requirement.
   She was transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] on supplemental oxygen. On arrival to the
   floor, she required 6LNC and was saturating 88%. ABG showed paO2 of 54.
   CXR was consistent with significant pulm edema. 40 mg IV lasix was
   given with 200cc UOP. Her saturation improved on hi flow venti mask
   saturating 95%.
   A CVL was placed but coiled into the SC.
   Because of her hypoxia from CHF and likely PNA (leukocytosis, low grade
   fever, sputum, cough), she was transferred to the MICU for further
   care.
   24 Hour Events:
   Vanco and aztreonam started.  CXR shows patchy opaicities- about the
   same as [**4-11**].
   Witnessed aspiration event during AM med administration.
   In the MICU she received lasix 60 IV with 500 cc u/o.
   She did not tolerate BIPAP
   After diuresis her oxygen requirement declined to 60% but while on
   rounds she became solmnolent and then unresponsive and hypoxemic
   shortly after removal of her right IJ CVL that was malpositioned.  Her
   lung exam was notable for bilateral breath sounds, diffuse expiratory
   wheeze.
   She was then emergently intubated.  Post intubation ABG notable for
   PO2=170 on 100% FIO2.  Solumedrol 125 IV given x 1 but not continued
   after vent mechanics revealed Ppeak=27, Pplat=25
   Placed on LTV ventilatory strategy.
   OGT placed with copious feculent material aspirated (airway clear on
   intubation per anesthesia).
   Allergies:
   Latex Gloves (Miscell) (Gloves
   Latex)
   Unknown;
   Aspirin
   Unknown;
   Colchicine
   Unknown;
   Antihistamine (Oral) (Diphenhydramine Hcl)
   Unknown;
   Quinolones
   Unknown;
   Vasodilators
   Misc. Classifier
   Unknown;
   Loratadine
   Unknown;
   Theophylline
   Unknown;
   Opioids: Morphine   Related
   Unknown;
   Cortisone
   Unknown;
   Iodine
   Unknown;
   Levaquin (Oral) (Levofloxacin)
   Unknown;
   More allergies, please see POE for details
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Vancomycin - [**2172-4-12**] 01:10 AM (day 1)
   Aztreonam- ordered but not given.
   Infusions:
   Propofol gtt
   Other ICU medications:
   Lorazepam (Ativan) - [**2172-4-11**] 11:58 PM
   Zocor
   Singulair
   Synthroid
   Plavix
   Norvasc
   Advair
   Cilium
   Protonix
   Heparin SC
   Nortrytiline
   Reglan
   Enalapril
   Immodium
   Sucralafate
   Cardizem 240 [**Hospital1 **]

   mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   Hypoxemia in the setting of history of underlying stage IV sarcoidosis,
   COPD, witnessed aspiration, known CHF- now intubated and meeting
   criteria for ARDS.  Given OGT output, aspiration pneumonia is most
   likely the dirving process for the current compensation.  Her complex
   GI issues also will require evaluation and were the original reason for
   transfer from OSH.  Agree with MICU resident plan of care and
   emphasize.
   PULM:
          Low tidal volume vent strategy.
          Goal Pplat<25
          Hold steroids as airway resistance not high.
          Sputum Cx
          Empiric ABX: Vanco, aztreonam and flagyl given allergies.
          -Will check Legionella
          Chest CT to evaluate underlying parenchymal lung disease.
   CV:
          CVP goal [**7-15**].
          TTE in AM
   GI:
          NPO.
          OGT to wall suction.
          GI consult to help work out her dismotility issues.
          ABD CT+ to r/o intra-abdominal abscess
   ENDO: QID FS
   RENAL Goal u/o 50 cc/hr
   ID- as above
   PPX: heparin sc, IV protonix.
   FAMILY: Met with son and daughter in law.  They affirmed full code
   status.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

   Disposition : MICU

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 62-year-old female with a complex medical history, including stage IV sarcoidosis, COPD, CHF, CVA, gastroparesis, and poorly controlled COPD. She has a history of multiple abdominal surgeries and has been admitted to the hospital five times in the past year for long hospital stays with extensive workup that has been negative.

The patient was admitted to the MICU with hypoxemia and was found to have significant pulmonary edema on a CXR. She was given IV lasix and diuresed, but then became hypoxemic and unresponsive after removal of her right IJ CVL, which was malpositioned. She was emergently intubated and placed on LTV ventilatory strategy.

The patient has a number of allergies, including latex, aspirin, colchicine, and quinolones, among others. She has received a number of medications, including vancomycin, aztreonam, and lasix, and has been given IVF and heparin SC.

The patient's physical examination is notable for bilateral breath sounds, diffuse expiratory wheeze, and a RASS score of -4. Her lab results show a WBC count of 18.8, Hct of 30.8, and Plt of 358.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypoxemia in the setting of history of underlying stage IV sarcoidosis, COPD, witnessed aspiration, known CHF- now intubated and meeting criteria for ARDS.
* Given OGT output, aspiration pneumonia is most likely the driving process for the current compensation.
* Complex GI issues will require evaluation and were the original reason for transfer from OSH.
* Agree with MICU resident plan of care and emphasize:

* PULM: Low tidal volume vent strategy, goal Pplat <25, hold steroids as airway resistance not high, sputum Cx, empiric ABX, and chest CT to evaluate underlying parenchymal lung disease.
* CV: CVP goal 7-15, TTE in AM.
* GI: NPO, OGT to wall suction, GI consult to help work out her dismotility issues, and ABD CT+ to r/o intra-abdominal abscess.
* ENDO: QID FS.
* RENAL: Goal u/o 50 cc/hr.
* ID: As above.
* PPX: Heparin SC, IV protonix.
* FAMILY: Met with son and daughter-in-law. They affirmed full code status.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Aspiration pneumonia
* ARDS
* Sepsis
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest
* GI bleeding
* Intra-abdominal abscess
* Cholangitis
* Biliary obstruction
* Pancreatitis

It is crucial to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan of care accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 80-year-old female with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, gastroparesis, Stage IV sarcoidosis, and poorly controlled COPD. She was admitted to the hospital for worsening GI symptoms and was transferred to the MICU due to hypoxemia. She developed gradually worsening dyspnea and required supplemental oxygen. A CVL was placed, but it was coiled into the SC. She was intubated after becoming somnolent and unresponsive, and post-intubation ABG showed PO2=170 on 100% FIO2. She was diagnosed with ARDS and aspiration pneumonia, and is being managed with a low tidal volume ventilation strategy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and aspiration pneumonia may lead to respiratory failure, which could worsen her condition.
2. Sepsis: The patient's aspiration pneumonia and underlying medical conditions may increase her risk of developing sepsis.
3. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's CHF and hypertension may lead to cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrest or congestive heart failure.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's gastroparesis and history of abdominal surgeries may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's CVA and underlying medical conditions may increase her risk of developing neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.
6. Infection: The patient's aspiration pneumonia and underlying medical conditions may increase her risk of developing infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections.
7. Renal failure: The patient's hypertension and underlying medical conditions may lead to renal failure.
8. Hepatic failure: The patient's underlying medical conditions may lead to hepatic failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust her ventilation strategy as needed.
2. Consider adding antibiotics to her treatment plan to prevent and treat potential infections.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely and adjust her treatment plan as needed to prevent and treat potential cardiovascular complications.
4. Consider adding medications to her treatment plan to help manage her gastroparesis and prevent gastrointestinal complications.
5. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and adjust her treatment plan as needed to prevent and treat potential neurological complications.
6. Consider adding medications to her treatment plan to help manage her hypertension and prevent potential cardiovascular complications.
7. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust her treatment plan as needed to prevent and treat potential renal failure.
8. Consider adding medications to her treatment plan to help manage her underlying medical conditions and prevent potential complications.

   In Summary, patient is 80 yo female with ILD, COPD and now found with
   severe hypoxemia in the setting of diffuse evidence of pulmonary
   infiltrates consistent with pulmonary edema.  She has had significant
   volume load although patient did have severe acute decompensation over
   past hours
this may be hydrostatic edema which would be supported by
   small bilateral effusions but patient with warm extremities and unclear
   underlying cardiac function.  She has had Lasix with minimal
   improvement.  Alternative sources are certainly aspiration with diffuse
   pneumonitis.  In addition
GI or alternative source for sepsis is
   certainly possible with evolution of diffuse Acute Lung Injury.
   Finally, viral pneumonia or atypical bacterial pneumonia is possible.
   PULM: Oxygen, defer on imaging.  IF she stabilizes obtain chest CT.
   Nebs for COPD.  Likely is aspirating.
   CV: hemodynamically stable. TBB even.  Obtain TTE.  Pull malpositioned
   CVL.
   GI: NPO.  Place NGT.  GI consult.
   ID: Vanco./aztreonam empricially.  F/U blood, urine, stool, and
   legionella.
   RENAL: Replete K
   PPX: Heparin SC.
   DISPO: FULL CODE.
   ACCESS: pull CVL and try for second PIV.  IF needed she will get a new
   line.
   Respiratory Failure
Clearly hypoxemic
   -Will continue with supplemental oxygen
   -Vanco/Aztreonam to continue
   -Lasix given and look for response over time
   -Will check Legionella
   -ACE-I for afterload reduction
   -Intubation discussed and may well be required and patient is amenable

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, chronic heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and inflammatory lung disease (ILD). She has had multiple abdominal surgeries, including a colovesicular fistula repair, and has been experiencing worsening diarrhea since the reversal of her ileostomy. She was recently admitted to the hospital for the fifth time in the past few months with persistent diarrhea and was transferred to the ICU for further care.

The patient's current condition is characterized by severe hypoxemia, pulmonary edema, and acute lung injury. She has a history of CHF and likely PNA (leukocytosis, low-grade fever, sputum, and cough). She was given 40mg IV lasix with 200cc urine output and her saturation improved on hi-flow venti mask. However, her central line is not at the proper place in the X-ray.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemia and pulmonary edema put her at risk for respiratory failure, which may require intubation.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's history of CHF and likely PNA may exacerbate her cardiac condition, leading to cardiac failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient's diarrhea and possible aspiration may lead to sepsis, which could worsen her respiratory and cardiac conditions.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's history of volume overload and possible sepsis may put her at risk for acute kidney injury.
5. GI complications: The patient's history of abdominal surgeries and diarrhea may lead to GI complications, such as perforation or bleeding.
6. Pneumonia: The patient's history of COPD and ILD may increase her risk for pneumonia, which could worsen her respiratory condition.

Plan:

1. Continue oxygen therapy and monitor the patient's oxygen saturation.
2. Continue IV lasix and monitor the patient's urine output.
3. Obtain a chest CT scan to evaluate the patient's pulmonary edema and possible aspiration.
4. Consider intubation if the patient's respiratory status worsens.
5. Continue empiric antibiotic therapy with vanco/aztreonam and monitor for signs of sepsis.
6. Replete potassium and monitor the patient's electrolyte levels.
7. Consider ACE-I for afterload reduction.
8. Place a nasogastric tube and consult with GI services.
9. Monitor the patient's renal function and consider dialysis if necessary.
10. Consider stress ulcer prophylaxis and VAP precautions.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of ILD and COPD who was admitted to the ICU with severe hypoxemia and diffuse pulmonary infiltrates consistent with pulmonary edema. She has had significant volume load and has experienced severe acute decompensation over the past hours. The patient has been treated with Lasix with minimal improvement, and alternative sources of sepsis, such as aspiration with diffuse pneumonitis, GI or alternative source of sepsis, and viral or atypical bacterial pneumonia, are possible.

Assessment:

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with severe hypoxemia and respiratory failure. She is hypoxemic and requires supplemental oxygen. The patient's cardiac function is unclear, and she has warm extremities. The patient's underlying condition is likely to be a combination of ILD, COPD, and pulmonary edema, which may be contributing to her respiratory failure.

Plan:

* Continue supplemental oxygen
* Continue Vanco/Aztreonam antibiotics
* Monitor for response to Lasix and adjust as needed
* Check for Legionella pneumonia
* Consider ACE-I for afterload reduction
* Discuss intubation with the patient and her family, as it may be necessary
* Continue ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she may require intubation and mechanical ventilation to support her breathing.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac function is unclear, and she may be at risk for cardiac failure, particularly if her respiratory status deteriorates further.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to her underlying condition and the presence of pulmonary infiltrates.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's kidney function is not well-documented, and she may be at risk for acute kidney injury due to her underlying condition and the use of nephrotoxic medications.
5. GI bleeding: The patient's GI tract is at risk for bleeding due to her underlying condition and the use of anticoagulant medications.
6. Pneumonia: The patient has a high risk of developing pneumonia due to her underlying condition and the presence of pulmonary infiltrates.
7. ARDS: The patient's condition is consistent with ARDS, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by inflammation and damage to the lungs.

TEXT:
Chief Complaint:
   HPI:
   80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple abdominal surgeries
   tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea. She had diverticulitis
   with colovesicular fistula in [**2169**] that required partial colonic
   resection and an ileostomy. In [**2170-12-4**], she had the ileostomy reversed
   and since then, she has had worsening of her diarrhea. In fact, since
   [**Month (only) **], she has been admitted to OSH 5 times for long hospital stays with
   extensive work up that has been negative so far. Most recently, she was
   admitted to OSH [**3-27**] where workup again has been negative. She has been
   getting IVF; lasix held. The family requested a transfer to [**Hospital1 19**] this
   morning for a 2nd opinion at a [**Hospital 7454**] care center. Of note this
   morning, she had flash pulm edema and was given 40mg IV lasix with
   [**2162**]+cc urine output.
   .
   She was transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] on supplemental oxygen. On arrival to the
   floor, she required 6LNC and was saturating 88%. ABG showed paO2 of 54.
   CXR was consistent with significant pulm edema. 40 mg IV lasix was
   given with 200cc UOP. Her saturation improved on hi flow venti mask
   saturating 95%. Of note, her central line is not at the proper place in
   the Xray. Because of her hypoxia from CHF and likely PNA (leukocytosis,
   low grade fever, sputum, cough), she was transferred to the MICU for
   further care.
   .
   At the OSH, she was started on sucrulfate for gastritis, reglan for
   mild gastroparesis and nortyptilline. She was also kept on immodium
   standing at 4mg [**Hospital1 7**] and psyllium. Her surgeons felt that she had a
   "short colon". She underwent colonscopy and EGD w/o diagnosis.

Chief Complaint:
   HPI:
   80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple abdominal surgeries
   tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea. She had diverticulitis
   with colovesicular fistula in [**2169**] that required partial colonic
   resection and an ileostomy. In [**2170-12-4**], she had the ileostomy reversed
   and since then, she has had worsening of her diarrhea. In fact, since
   [**Month (only) **], she has been admitted to OSH 5 times for long hospital stays with
   extensive work up that has been negative so far. Most recently, she was
   admitted to OSH [**3-27**] where workup again has been negative. She has been
   getting IVF; lasix held. The family requested a transfer to [**Hospital1 19**] this
   morning for a 2nd opinion at a [**Hospital 7454**] care center. Of note this
   morning, she had flash pulm edema and was given 40mg IV lasix with
   [**2162**]+cc urine output.
   .
   She was transferred to [**Hospital1 19**] on supplemental oxygen. On arrival to the
   floor, she required 6LNC and was saturating 88%. ABG showed paO2 of 54.
   CXR was consistent with significant pulm edema. 40 mg IV lasix was
   given with 200cc UOP. Her saturation improved on hi flow venti mask
   saturating 95%. Of note, her central line is not at the proper place in
   the Xray. Because of her hypoxia from CHF and likely PNA (leukocytosis,
   low grade fever, sputum, cough), she was transferred to the MICU for
   further care.
   .
   At the OSH, she was started on sucrulfate for gastritis, reglan for
   mild gastroparesis and nortyptilline. She was also kept on immodium
   standing at 4mg [**Hospital1 7**] and psyllium. Her surgeons felt that she had a
   "short colon". She underwent colonscopy and EGD w/o diagnosis.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a complex medical history, including CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the ICU with severe hypoxemia, diffuse pulmonary infiltrates consistent with pulmonary edema, and worsening diarrhea. She has had a history of diverticulitis with colovesicular fistula and has undergone multiple surgeries, including partial colonic resection and ileostomy reversal. Despite treatment with Lasix, her condition has not improved, and she requires supplemental oxygen.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's severe hypoxemia and diffuse pulmonary infiltrates put her at risk for respiratory failure, which may require intubation.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of CHF and CAD increases her risk for cardiac complications, such as acute decompensation, arrhythmias, or heart failure.
3. Infection: The patient's diarrhea and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of infection, which could be caused by aspiration, GI or alternative source, or atypical bacterial pneumonia.
4. Sepsis: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and elevated lactate acid levels suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could be caused by a variety of sources, including GI, pulmonary, or systemic infections.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of diverticulitis and colovesicular fistula increases her risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation, abscess, or bleeding.
6. Renal Complications: The patient's history of CHF and CAD increases her risk for renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's history of CVA and ILD increases her risk for neurological complications, such as stroke, seizures, or cognitive impairment.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management of her respiratory, cardiac, and gastrointestinal symptoms. She should continue to receive supplemental oxygen, Lasix, and antibiotics. Her cardiac function should be monitored closely, and consideration should be given to intubation if her condition deteriorates. The patient's gastrointestinal symptoms should be managed with anti-diarrheal medications and consideration should be given to further imaging or endoscopy to rule out underlying causes. The patient's renal function should be monitored closely, and consideration should be given to further imaging or intervention if necessary. The patient's neurological function should be monitored closely, and consideration should be given to further imaging or intervention if necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU, receiving non-invasive ventilation and multi-lumen insertion. They have a history of allergies, including latex, and are taking various medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and vasodilators. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.8F, heart rate of 87 bpm, and blood pressure of 137/46 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy and have a SpO2 of 93%. The patient's respiratory support is set to standby mode, with a ventilator mode and FiO2 of 60%. 

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, hematocrit, and platelet count, with normal creatinine and troponin-T levels. Their liver enzymes are slightly elevated, and their calcium, magnesium, and phosphate levels are within normal range.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxemia: The patient's SpO2 is 93%, which may indicate hypoxemia, especially considering their respiratory support.
2. Delirium/Confusion: The patient's mental status is not well-documented, but the presence of delirium or confusion is a common complication in critically ill patients.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory support and lab results may indicate the presence of pneumonia.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count, fever, and lab results may indicate the presence of sepsis.
5. DVT: The patient's risk of developing DVT is high due to their immobility and the presence of central venous catheters.
6. Stress Ulcer: The patient's critical illness and medications may increase their risk of developing stress ulcers.
7. VAP: The patient's respiratory support and the presence of central venous catheters may increase their risk of developing VAP.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU who has been experiencing respiratory distress. The patient's breathing has improved slightly with the initiation of non-invasive ventilation and multi-lumen insertion.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1C, heart rate of 87 bpm, and blood pressure of 137/46 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 93% on high-flow neb with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 60%.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 18.8 K/uL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 30.8%
* Platelet count (Plt): 358 K/uL
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.8 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Total CO2 (TCO2): 34 mmHg
* Glucose: 95 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show slightly improved bilateral infiltrates on the chest X-ray (CXR).

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypoxemia: The patient's oxygen saturation is 93% on high-flow neb, indicating a mild degree of hypoxemia.
* Delirium/Confusion: The patient's mental status is not well-documented, but it is noted that the patient did not tolerate bi-level positive airway pressure (BiPap) and required sedation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemia and requirement for non-invasive ventilation suggest that the patient is at risk for respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's elevated WBC count and CRP suggest that the patient may be at risk for sepsis.
* Pneumonia: The patient's CXR shows bilateral infiltrates, which could be indicative of pneumonia.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's blood pressure is slightly elevated, which could be indicative of cardiovascular instability.
* Delirium: The patient's mental status is not well-documented, but it is noted that the patient did not tolerate BiPap and required sedation, which could be indicative of delirium.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple abdominal surgeries
   tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea who is now admitted to
   MICU for hypoxia.
   .
   #  Hypoxia: PaO2 54 on NC and pt in distress. Tecnichally she meets
   criteria for ARDS> CXR with central patchy infiltrates that could
   represent pulmonary edema vs underlying ILD. Patient has hx ILD but is
   not on home O2. There is no record of CXR on admission to OSH. The
   hypoxia and respiratory distress appear to be an acute change as of
   today. In addition, she is noted to have mild bibasilar crackles on
   exam on admission to [**Hospital3 4015**] but now has diffuse crackles all
   the way up the lung. BNP from OSH is slightly elevated. Taken together
   this suggests that she has acute pulmonary edema. However, idffuse
   infiltrates can also aoccur with ARDS, viral PNA or atypical PNA;
   aspiration is also possible. She does have an elevated WBC and the
   edema may be hiding infiltrates. She has no risk factors for ARDS - no
   sepsis, no pacreatitis, no transfusion. It is unlikely that she would
   have developed viral PNA while at OSH.  We have no prior echo  but pt
   states she has had problems with fluid in her lungs before. EKG is
   notable for IVCD, non-specific Twave changes and small ST depressions
   in V5/V6. She denies CP but could still have had an MI. She is not
   hypertensive. It is unkown if she had afib RVR at OSh but appers to be
   in NSR now at a rate of 92. She has received lasix 40mg IV. Her records
   state that she is allergic to morphine and demerol as well as
   isosorbide.
   - start BiPap
   - ACEi- for afterload given allergy to nitrites
   - diurese 500cc in addition to 400cc already
   - obtain BNP
   - cont Advair and Spiriva
   - cont Amlodipine 5mg daily
   - r/o MI
   - obtain an echo
   - Vanc, Aztreonam for ? HAP
   .
   # Leukocytosis: New as of today. No localizing signs other than
   respiratory failure. Benign abd.
   - stool cx
   - UA and Ux
   - sputum cx
   - given respiratory failure, will give empric abx; Vanc and Aztreonam
   .
   # hx COPD, ? hx ILD: not on home O2
   - cont Advair and Spiriva and Singulair
   .
   # Diarrhea: has had extensive w/u without diagnosis. Leading diagnosis
   is short gut ("short colon") although I beleive short colon does not
   typically cause diarrhea. Infections have been repeated r/o.
   Microscopic colitis is under consideration and biopsies are pending at
   OSH. Likewise labs for VIPoma, carcinoid syndrom and fat malabsorbtion
   are pending. Pancreatic insufficiency should also be considered.
   - cont Metamucil, nortryptyline and immodium
   - repeat C.diff, O/P, cryto/isosporidium
   - obtain stool na and K for stool osms
   - f/u VIP, 5HIAA, fecal fat from OSH
   - obtain records of colon biopsy and CT scans
   - hold lactobacillus as non-formulary
   .
   # Gastritis/ GERD:
   - cont omeprazole 20 [**Hospital1 7**] , sucrulfate
   .
   # Gastroparesis:
   - cont  reglan 10mg QIDAHC
    .
   # CAD: not on ASA? will need to ask pt when off BiPap
   - cont plavix
   - cont simvastatin
   .
   # Hx Afib: in NSR now at HR 90
   - cont diltiazem 240mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH was 3.71 at OSH ahd Levothyroxine dose appears to
   have been decreased from 200mg to 100mg daily.
   .
   # FEN:  NPO while on BiPap
   .
   # ACCESS: one PIV, need to pull central line,  ordered a PICC
   # CODE: full, confirmed w son and patient
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   22 Gauge - [**2172-4-11**] 11:14 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2172-4-12**] 02:24 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old female with a complex medical history, including CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and respiratory distress, and is currently on non-invasive ventilation and multi-lumen catheter.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Hypoxemia with a PaO2 of 54 on NC, and diffuse crackles throughout the lung fields.
* Cardiovascular: Normal sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 87 bpm, and a blood pressure of 137/46 mmHg.
* Neurological: Delirium and confusion, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 13.
* Hemodynamic: Fluid overload with a central venous pressure (CVP) of 12 mmHg, and a pulmonary artery occlusion pressure (PAOP) of 18 mmHg.
* Laboratory: Leukocytosis with a white blood cell count (WBC) of 18.8 K/uL, and elevated liver enzymes (ALT and AST).
* Imaging: CXR shows bilateral infiltrates, consistent with acute pulmonary edema or ARDS.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Hypoxemia: PaO2 of 54 on NC, with diffuse crackles throughout the lung fields.
* Respiratory failure: Requires non-invasive ventilation and multi-lumen catheter.
* Delirium and confusion: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 13.
* Fluid overload: Central venous pressure (CVP) of 12 mmHg, and pulmonary artery occlusion pressure (PAOP) of 18 mmHg.
* Leukocytosis: WBC of 18.8 K/uL.
* Elevated liver enzymes: ALT and AST.
* Acute pulmonary edema or ARDS: CXR shows bilateral infiltrates.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Start BiPap and adjust as needed.
* Continue ACEi for afterload reduction.
* Diuresis with 500cc of fluid in addition to 400cc already given.
* Obtain BNP and troponin-T levels.
* R/O MI.
* Obtain an echo.
* Continue Advair and Spiriva.
* Contain Amlodipine 5mg daily.
* R/O HAP with Vanc and Aztreonam.
* Contain Metamucil, nortryptyline, and immodium.
* Repeat C.diff, O/P, and cryto/isosporidium.
* Obtain stool Na and K for stool osms.
* F/U VIP, 5HIAA, and fecal fat from OSH.
* Obtain records of colon biopsy and CT scans.
* Hold lactobacillus as non-formulary.

The patient's disposition is to remain in the ICU for further management and monitoring.

   tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea who is now admitted to
   MICU for hypoxia.
   .
   #  Hypoxia: PaO2 54 on NC and pt in distress. Tecnichally she meets
   criteria for ARDS> CXR with central patchy infiltrates that could
   represent pulmonary edema vs underlying ILD. Patient has hx ILD but is
   not on home O2. There is no record of CXR on admission to OSH. The
   hypoxia and respiratory distress appear to be an acute change as of
   today. In addition, she is noted to have mild bibasilar crackles on
   exam on admission to [**Hospital3 4015**] but now has diffuse crackles all
   the way up the lung. BNP from OSH is slightly elevated. Taken together
   this suggests that she has acute pulmonary edema. However, idffuse
   infiltrates can also aoccur with ARDS, viral PNA or atypical PNA;
   aspiration is also possible. She does have an elevated WBC and the
   edema may be hiding infiltrates. She has no risk factors for ARDS - no
   sepsis, no pacreatitis, no transfusion. It is unlikely that she would
   have developed viral PNA while at OSH.  We have no prior echo  but pt
   states she has had problems with fluid in her lungs before. EKG is
   notable for IVCD, non-specific Twave changes and small ST depressions
   in V5/V6. She denies CP but could still have had an MI. She is not
   hypertensive. It is unkown if she had afib RVR at OSh but appers to be
   in NSR now at a rate of 92. She has received lasix 40mg IV. Her records
   state that she is allergic to morphine and demerol as well as
   isosorbide.
   - start BiPap
   - ACEi- for afterload given allergy to nitrites
   - diurese 500cc in addition to 400cc already
   - obtain BNP
   - cont Advair and Spiriva
   - cont Amlodipine 5mg daily
   - r/o MI
   - obtain an echo
   - Vanc, Aztreonam for ? HAP
   .
   # Leukocytosis: New as of today. No localizing signs other than
   respiratory failure. Benign abd.
   - stool cx
   - UA and Ux
   - sputum cx
   - given respiratory failure, will give empric abx; Vanc and Aztreonam
   .
   # hx COPD, ? hx ILD: not on home O2
   - cont Advair and Spiriva and Singulair
   .
   # Diarrhea: has had extensive w/u without diagnosis. Leading diagnosis
   is short gut ("short colon") although I beleive short colon does not
   typically cause diarrhea. Infections have been repeated r/o.
   Microscopic colitis is under consideration and biopsies are pending at
   OSH. Likewise labs for VIPoma, carcinoid syndrom and fat malabsorbtion
   are pending. Pancreatic insufficiency should also be considered.
   - cont Metamucil, nortryptyline and immodium
   - repeat C.diff, O/P, cryto/isosporidium
   - obtain stool na and K for stool osms
   - f/u VIP, 5HIAA, fecal fat from OSH
   - obtain records of colon biopsy and CT scans
   - hold lactobacillus as non-formulary
   .
   # Gastritis/ GERD:
   - cont omeprazole 20 [**Hospital1 7**] , sucrulfate
   .
   # Gastroparesis:
   - cont  reglan 10mg QIDAHC
    .
   # CAD: not on ASA? will need to ask pt when off BiPap
   - cont plavix
   - cont simvastatin
   .
   # Hx Afib: in NSR now at HR 90
   - cont diltiazem 240mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH was 3.71 at OSH ahd Levothyroxine dose appears to
   have been decreased from 200mg to 100mg daily.
   .
   # FEN:  NPO while on BiPap
   .
   # ACCESS: one PIV, need to pull central line,  ordered a PICC
   # CODE: full, confirmed w son and patient
   ICU Care

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Hypoxemia: The patient's PaO2 is 54 on NC, and they are in distress. This suggests that the patient has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), pulmonary edema, or another underlying lung condition.
2. Delirium/Confusion: The patient is experiencing delirium and confusion, which can be a result of hypoxemia, sepsis, or other underlying medical conditions.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient has a new onset of leukocytosis, which can be a sign of infection or inflammation.
4. Diarrhea: The patient has had extensive workup without diagnosis, and the leading diagnosis is short gut or microscopic colitis. However, other possibilities such as infections, VIPoma, carcinoid syndrome, or pancreatic insufficiency should also be considered.
5. Gastritis/GERD: The patient has a history of gastritis and GERD, which can increase the risk of bleeding and aspiration.
6. Gastroparesis: The patient has gastroparesis, which can lead to delayed gastric emptying, nausea, and vomiting.
7. CAD: The patient has a history of CAD, which can increase the risk of cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which can affect metabolism, energy levels, and overall health.
9. FEN: The patient is NPO (nothing by mouth) while on BiPap, which can lead to malnutrition and dehydration if not properly managed.
10. DVT: The patient has a central line, which increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).

The patient's medical history and current condition suggest that they are at risk for several medical complications. It is essential to monitor their condition closely and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient's condition is as follows:

* The patient is a 80-year-old woman with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, who was admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and respiratory distress.
* The patient's hypoxia is acute, with a PaO2 of 54 on NC, and she meets criteria for ARDS. The CXR shows central patchy infiltrates that could represent pulmonary edema or underlying ILD.
* The patient has mild bibasilar crackles on exam, but now has diffuse crackles all the way up the lung, suggesting acute pulmonary edema. However, diffuse infiltrates can also occur with ARDS, viral PNA, or atypical PNA.
* The patient has no risk factors for ARDS, and it is unlikely that she developed viral PNA while at OSH.
* The patient has received lasix 40mg IV, and her records state that she is allergic to morphine and demerol as well as isosorbide.
* The patient has leukocytosis, which is new as of today, with no localizing signs other than respiratory failure.
* The patient has a history of COPD and ILD, but is not on home O2.
* The patient has had extensive w/u for diarrhea without diagnosis, and the leading diagnosis is short gut ("short colon"), although the doctor believes short colon does not typically cause diarrhea.
* The patient has been given respiratory failure, and will receive empiric abx with Vanc and Aztreonam.
* The patient has a history of gastroparesis, and is taking reglan 10mg QID.
* The patient has a history of CAD, and is taking plavix and simvastatin.
* The patient has a history of afib, and is taking diltiazem 240mg.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and respiratory distress could lead to respiratory failure, which could be life-threatening.
* Pneumonia: The patient's diffuse infiltrates on CXR could be indicative of pneumonia, which could lead to further respiratory distress and potential sepsis.
* Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and respiratory failure could lead to sepsis, which could be life-threatening.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastroparesis and history of bleeding could lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, which could be life-threatening.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's history of CAD and afib could lead to cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or arrhythmias.
* Thyroid complications: The patient's hypothyroidism could lead to thyroid-related complications, such as hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism.
* Infection: The patient's respiratory failure and leukocytosis could lead to infection, which could be life-threatening.
* Malnutrition: The patient's respiratory failure and inability to eat could lead to malnutrition, which could be life-threatening.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a complex medical history, including CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. He was transferred to the MICU for hypoxia and is currently on non-invasive ventilation. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 87-89 bpm, blood pressure of 127-137/46-51 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 93%. He has a history of hypoxemia, and his CXR shows central patchy infiltrates that could represent pulmonary edema or underlying ILD.

The patient has a variety of medical issues, including:

* Leukocytosis: New onset, with no localizing signs other than respiratory failure. Benign abdominal examination.
* Diarrhea: Has had extensive work-up without diagnosis. Leading diagnosis is short gut ("short colon"), but microscopic colitis is also a consideration.
* Gastritis/GERD: Currently on proton pump inhibitor (PPI) IV, with a plan to avoid PO PPI.
* Gastroparesis: Currently on metoclopramide 10mg IV q6 hours.
* Hypokalemia: Received 60mg PO K today, with plans to check electrolytes later.
* CAD: Not on aspirin, but will need to ask patient when off BiPap.
* Hx Afib: Currently in normal sinus rhythm (NSR) at a heart rate of 90 bpm.
* Hypothyroidism: TSH was 3.71 at OSH, and levothyroxine dose appears to have been decreased from 200mg to 100mg daily.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemia and respiratory failure could worsen, leading to further complications such as pneumonia or respiratory arrest.
* Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and diarrhea could be indicative of an underlying infection, which could spread to other parts of the body.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's gastroparesis and hypokalemia could lead to further gastrointestinal complications, such as constipation or bowel obstruction.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's CAD and hypoxemia could lead to further cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
* Neurological complications: The patient's hypoxemia and respiratory failure could lead to further neurological complications, such as seizures or brain injury.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his various medical issues to prevent further complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old female with a complex medical history, including CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the MICU for worsening hypoxia and central patchy infiltrates on her CXR, which could represent pulmonary edema or underlying ILD.

The patient had a witnessed aspiration event yesterday, followed by a hypoxic event where she became unresponsive and required emergent intubation. She was ventilated with an ARDSnet protocol, and her P/F ratio is 177. She also has bilateral infiltrates on her CXR.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. Hypoxemia: The patient has severe hypoxemia, requiring ventilator support and oxygen therapy.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which may be related to her respiratory failure or underlying infection.
3. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient has an electrolyte imbalance, with a potassium level of 2.2 mmol/L and a magnesium level of 0.8 mmol/L.
4. Delirium/confusion: The patient is sedated and has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 12, indicating confusion and disorientation.
5. Gastrointestinal issues: The patient has diarrhea, which is likely related to her underlying medical conditions and medications. She also has gastritis/GERD, which is being managed with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, requiring further ventilator support or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and electrolyte imbalance may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastritis/GERD and diarrhea may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, which could worsen her respiratory failure.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's CAD and CHF may worsen, leading to cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
5. Infection: The patient's underlying medical conditions and immunosuppression may increase her risk of infection, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, or skin infections.

To manage these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management of her respiratory, cardiovascular, and gastrointestinal systems. She should receive targeted therapy for her underlying medical conditions, including antibiotics for potential infections and medications to manage her respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old female admitted to the MICU with worsening hypoxia and CXR with central patchy infiltrates that could represent pulmonary edema vs underlying ILD. She has a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries.

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory: Hypoxemic with a P/F ratio of 177 and CXR with bilateral infiltrates, requiring invasive ventilation with ARDSnet protocol.
* Cardiovascular: Atrial fibrillation (AF) with a heart rate of 108 bpm, but currently in normal sinus rhythm (NSR) at a heart rate of 90 bpm.
* Neurological: Sedated and unable to provide history, with no neurological examination findings documented.
* Gastrointestinal: Diarrhea with extensive workup without diagnosis, leading diagnosis of short gut ("short colon") although I believe short colon does not typically cause diarrhea. Infections have been ruled out.
* Laboratory results:
	+ WBC: 18.8
	+ Hct: 30.8
	+ Plt: 358
	+ Cr: 0.8
	+ TropT: <0.01
	+ TCO2: 34
	+ Glucose: 95
	+ Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 19.1/63.0/1.8, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 40/<0.01/<0.01, ALT/AST: 9-23, Alk Phos/T Bili: 81/1.1, Lactic Acid: 0.9 mmol/L, LDH: 331 IU/L, Ca++: 7.9 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL, PO4: 4.5 mg/dL

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic condition can lead to further respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of CAD, CHF, and AF increases her risk for cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and myocardial infarction.
3. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diarrhea and history of multiple abdominal surgeries increase her risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as infection, bleeding, and perforation.
4. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and presence of central lines increase her risk for infection, particularly pneumonia and bloodstream infections.
5. Thromboembolic events: The patient's history of CAD and presence of central lines increase her risk for thromboembolic events, such as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's history of hypothyroidism and decreased Levothyroxine dose may require close monitoring and potential adjustment of her thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
7. Electrolyte and fluid disorders: The patient's history of COPD and ILD may lead to electrolyte and fluid disorders, such as hypokalemia and hypophosphatemia.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following interventions are recommended:

1. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with invasive ventilation and ARDSnet protocol.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely, including heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac enzymes.
3. Continue to manage the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms with anti-diarrheal agents and consider further workup for underlying causes.
4. Monitor the patient's laboratory results closely, including electrolyte and fluid levels, and adjust her medications as needed.
5. Consider further workup for underlying causes of the patient's diarrhea, including short gut syndrome, infections, and pancreatic insufficiency.
6. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and consider starting total parenteral nutrition (TPN) if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's glycemic control closely and adjust her insulin therapy as needed.

   80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple abdominal surgeries
   tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea who is now admitted to
   MICU for hypoxia.
   .
   # Hypoxia Resp Failure: Patient was admitted with worsening hypoxia and
   CXR with central patchy infiltrates that could represent pulmonary
   edema vs underlying ILD. Patient has hx ILD but is not on home O2. This
   morning, she had a witnessed aspiration yesterday and then had a
   hypoxic event where she acutely desated and became unresponsive
   requiring emergent intubation. P/F ratio 177 and CXR with bilateral
   infiltrates and she was ventilated with ardsnet protocol.
   - Vent: continue to wean FiO2 and PEEP using ardsnet tidal volumes
   tolerating PaO2 70-80
   - continue d3 Vanc / d3 aztreonam for empriric coverage of HAP; d2 for
   flagyl for aspiration pna
   - echo today to eval EF
   - continue ipratropium q 6 and albuterol q4hrs PRN
   - will obtain CT chest / abdomen / pelvis today, consider bronchoscopy
   - acquire OSH CXR / CT chest imaging
   .
   # Leukocytosis: She had new leukocytosis yesterday, but today is
   trending down. Sputum with 1+ GPCs
   - f/u stool cx
   - UCx: pending
   - sputum cx: GPCs
   - legionella UA
   - check blood cx, although lower yield as will have already received
   abx
   - given respiratory failure, will give empric abx; Vanc and Aztreonam
   - IVF boluses PRN
   .
   # hx COPD, ? hx ILD: not on home O2.
   - repeat CT chest when able
   - cont Advair and Singulair
   .
   # Diarrhea: has had extensive w/u without diagnosis. Leading diagnosis
   is short gut ("short colon") although I beleive short colon does not
   typically cause diarrhea. Infections have been repeated r/o.
   Microscopic colitis is under consideration and biopsies are pending at
   OSH. Likewise labs for VIPoma, carcinoid syndrom and fat malabsorbtion
   are pending. Pancreatic insufficiency should also be considered.
   - cont Metamucil, nortriptyline
   - d/c immodium until stool cx neg
   - repeat C.diff, O/P, cryto/isosporidium
   - obtain stool na and K for stool osms -> stool currently not liquiid
   enough
   - f/u VIP, 5HIAA, fecal fat from OSH
   - colon biopsy on [**3-12**] at OSH still pending
   - consult GI today
   - CT chest / abdomen / pelvis
   .
   # Gastritis/ GERD:
   - cont PP IV, avoid PO PPI
   - d/c sucrulfate
   .
   # CAD: not on ASA? will need to ask pt when off BiPap
   -  cont plavix
   -  d/c simvastatin
   .
   # Hx Afib: in NSR now at HR 90. Last night had episode of afib with RVR
   - cont diltiazem 240mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH was 3.71 at OSH ahd Levothyroxine dose appears to
   have been decreased from 200mg to 100mg daily.
   # CODE: full, confirmed w son and patient
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: consider starting TF

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old female with a complex medical history, including CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries. She was admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and worsening respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a P/F ratio of 177. She has bilateral infiltrates on CXR and is receiving ARDSnet ventilation.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and recently had an episode of AFib with RVR, which was resolved with 500cc IVF.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has diarrhea, which is believed to be related to short gut syndrome. She has had extensive workup without a diagnosis, and biopsies are pending.
* Hematology: The patient has leukocytosis, which is trending down. Sputum cultures are pending, and empric antibiotics have been started.
* Electrolytes and fluids: The patient has an electrolyte and fluid disorder, which is being managed with IVF boluses and electrolyte supplements.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is already intubated and on mechanical ventilation, but there is a risk of further respiratory deterioration.
* Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to her respiratory failure, leukocytosis, and empric antibiotics.
* Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and may be at risk of further cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has diarrhea and may be at risk of further gastrointestinal complications, such as dehydration or electrolyte imbalances.
* Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing infections, particularly respiratory infections, due to her intubation and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue weaning FiO2 and PEEP using ARDSnet tidal volumes
* Continue empric antibiotics for HAP and aspiration pneumonia
* Obtain CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis today
* Consider bronchoscopy
* Acquire OSH CXR and CT chest imaging
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and cardiac complications
* Continue to manage the patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder
* Consider starting total parenteral nutrition (TF) and continuing to manage the patient's glycemic control.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities and ongoing medical management. The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory compromise: The patient is receiving invasive ventilation, and their oxygen saturation is 91%. The arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 148, indicating moderate hypoxemia.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient has atrial fibrillation, and their blood pressure is labile, ranging from 92/44 mmHg to 129/53 mmHg.
3. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is 3 mmHg, indicating possible hypovolemia. Their fluid balance shows a total intake of 1,793 mL and an output of 1,483 mL, with a net balance of 310 mL.
4. Renal dysfunction: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, ranging from 0.8 to 1.0 mg/dL.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has hypocalcemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, indicating possible infection or inflammation.
7. Delirium and confusion: The patient's mental status is impaired, and they are not assessed for movement, tone, or skin integrity.
8. Nutritional compromise: The patient's nutritional status is not well-documented, but they are receiving some form of nutrition.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory compromise and hypoxemia make them susceptible to pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and potential electrolyte imbalance increase their risk of developing sepsis.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation and labile blood pressure make them susceptible to cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and electrolyte imbalance increase their risk of developing acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
5. Delirium and prolonged ICU stay: The patient's impaired mental status and lack of mobility increase their risk of developing delirium and prolonging their ICU stay.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's compromised nutritional status may lead to malnutrition, which can worsen their overall condition.
7. Vascular complications: The patient's multiple lines and catheters increase their risk of developing vascular complications, such as thrombosis or infection.

Based on the patient's current condition, it is essential to continue monitoring their vital signs, respiratory status, and hemodynamic stability. Additionally, the patient's electrolyte and fluid balance should be closely monitored and managed to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old female with a complex medical history, including stage IV sarcoidosis, COPD, and chronic heart failure (CHF). She was intubated for hypoxemic arrest and is currently receiving invasive ventilation. The patient's condition is complicated by aspiration pneumonia, which is likely the driving process for her current respiratory distress.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.6C (99.7F)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 98/48 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 29 inspirations per minute (IPM)
* Oxygen saturation: 91%
* Atrial fibrillation (AF) with rapid ventricular rate (RVR)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 11.5 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 18.8 K/uL
* Platelet count: 358 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L
* LDH: 331 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.5 mg/dL
* BNP: 1100 pg/mL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Suspecting acute aspiration and planning to send sputum if produced
* Obtaining old CT scans and x-rays to evaluate chronic lung disease
* Continuing nebulizers and bronchodilators as needed
* Holding enalapril and norvasc and continuing diltiazem
* Giving small boluses of fluid for CVP and urine output
* Reviewing OSH studies regarding workup of chronic diarrhea
* Rescanning abdomen and following up biopsies from OSH
* Consulting GI for chronic diarrhea
* Continuing synthroid and other medications as needed

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress may worsen, leading to respiratory failure and the need for more aggressive respiratory support.
* Sepsis: The patient's aspiration pneumonia and chronic lung disease may increase her risk of developing sepsis.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's atrial fibrillation and chronic heart failure may lead to cardiovascular instability and the need for more aggressive cardiovascular support.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's chronic diarrhea and chronic lung disease may increase her risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Malnutrition: The patient's short gut syndrome and chronic diarrhea may lead to malnutrition and the need for nutritional support.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress as follows:

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of stage IV sarcoidosis, COPD, and chronic heart failure (CHF). She was intubated due to hypoxemic arrest and is currently being treated in the ICU for respiratory failure. The patient has a complex GI history, including diverticulitis and multiple colectomies, and was transferred from another hospital for a second opinion on her diarrhea.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6C, heart rate of 83 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 98/48 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 91%, and she is receiving supplemental oxygen through an endotracheal tube.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels. Her troponin-T level is less than 0.01 ng/mL, and her brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level is 1100 pg/mL.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Respiratory support: The patient will continue to receive mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute.
2. Cardiovascular support: The patient will receive vasopressor support to maintain her blood pressure, and her cardiac output will be monitored.
3. Gastrointestinal support: The patient will receive tube feeds, and a nutrition consult will be obtained for short-gut feeding.
4. Endocrine support: The patient will continue to receive thyroid hormone replacement therapy with synthroid.
5. Hematology support: The patient will receive blood transfusions as needed to maintain her hemoglobin level.
6. Infection control: The patient will receive antibiotics to prevent and treat infections.
7. Pain management: The patient will receive pain medication as needed to manage her discomfort.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's underlying ILD/COPD may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's CHF may worsen, leading to cardiac arrest or heart failure.
3. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diarrhea may worsen, leading to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.
4. Infection: The patient may develop pneumonia or other infections, which could worsen her condition.
5. Bleeding: The patient may develop bleeding complications due to her platelet count and coagulopathy.
6. Malnutrition: The patient may develop malnutrition due to her short-gut syndrome and inability to absorb nutrients.

To mitigate these complications, the patient will require close monitoring and management by the ICU team, as well as consultation with specialists in gastroenterology, cardiology, and hematology.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of stage IV sarcoidosis, COPD, and chronic heart failure (CHF). She was intubated for hypoxemic arrest and is currently mechanically ventilated. The patient has been experiencing diarrhea, which is likely related to her underlying GI issues. She has also developed aspiration pneumonia, which is suspected to be the driving process for her current respiratory compromise.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 98/48 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 91% on 50% FiO2. Her respiratory support includes invasive ventilation, with a peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 29 cmH2O and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of chronic diarrhea, with an elevated troponin-T level of <0.01 ng/mL and an elevated BNP level of 1100 pg/mL. Her coagulation profile is abnormal, with an elevated INR of 1.8. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly low potassium level of 3.5 mEq/L.

The patient's physical examination reveals bilateral wheezing and rhonchi in the lungs, as well as signs of chronic heart failure, including jugular venous distension and bilateral pedal edema.

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's aspiration pneumonia and chronic lung disease may lead to respiratory failure, which could require increased ventilatory support or even extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's chronic heart failure and hypoxemia may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or even cardiac arrest.
3. GI complications: The patient's chronic diarrhea and malabsorption may lead to electrolyte imbalances, dehydration, or even small bowel obstruction.
4. Infection: The patient's aspiration pneumonia and chronic lung disease may increase her risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or other infections.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's abnormal coagulation profile may increase her risk of bleeding complications, particularly with invasive procedures or medications.

Given the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to closely monitor her vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination findings to detect any potential complications early on.

   80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple abdominal surgeries
   tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea who is now admitted to
   MICU for hypoxia.
   .
   # Hypoxia Resp Failure: Patient was admitted with worsening hypoxia and
   CXR with central patchy infiltrates that could represent pulmonary
   edema vs underlying ILD. Patient has hx ILD but is not on home O2. This
   morning, she had a witnessed aspiration yesterday and then had a
   hypoxic event where she acutely desated and became unresponsive
   requiring emergent intubation. P/F ratio 177 and CXR with bilateral
   infiltrates and she was ventilated with ardsnet protocol.
   - Vent: continue to wean FiO2 and PEEP using ardsnet tidal volumes
   tolerating PaO2 70-80
   - continue d3 Vanc / d3 aztreonam for empriric coverage of HAP; d2 for
   flagyl for aspiration pna
   - echo today to eval EF
   - continue ipratropium q 6 and albuterol q4hrs PRN
   - will obtain CT chest / abdomen / pelvis today, consider bronchoscopy
   - acquire OSH CXR / CT chest imaging
   .
   # Leukocytosis: She had new leukocytosis yesterday, but today is
   trending down. Sputum with 1+ GPCs
   - f/u stool cx
   - UCx: pending
   - sputum cx: GPCs
   - legionella UA
   - check blood cx, although lower yield as will have already received
   abx
   - given respiratory failure, will give empric abx; Vanc and Aztreonam
   - IVF boluses PRN
   .
   # hx COPD, ? hx ILD: not on home O2.
   - repeat CT chest when able
   - cont Advair and Singulair
   .
   # Diarrhea: has had extensive w/u without diagnosis. Leading diagnosis

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old female admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and respiratory failure. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and chronic heart failure (CHF). She was transferred from OSH for a second opinion on her diarrhea, which has been extensive and undiagnosed.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 190. She has diffuse crackles on lung examination and a CT chest showing diffuse ground glass opacity with areas of normal lung, consistent with infection or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* Diarrhea: The patient has had extensive workup without diagnosis. The leading diagnosis is short gut syndrome, but microscopic colitis is also being considered. Biopsies are pending at OSH.
* Leukocytosis: The patient has new leukocytosis, which is trending down. Sputum culture shows 1+ GPCs, and sputum Gram stain is pending.
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient has hypotension and low urine output, requiring IVF boluses.
* Delirium/confusion: The patient is intubated and sedated, making it difficult to assess her mental status.

The patient's medications include:

* Propofol for sedation
* Heparin for prophylaxis
* Pantoprazole for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
* Metronidazole for aspiration pneumonia
* Vancomycin and aztreonam for empirical coverage of hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP)
* Ipratropium and albuterol for bronchodilation
* Diltiazem for rate control

The patient's lab results show:

* White blood cell count: 18.8-20.0 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 10.5-11.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 358-376 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.8-0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L
* LDH: 331 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.4 mg/dL

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to increased oxygen requirements, ventilator dependence, and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and sputum culture results suggest the possibility of infection. Empirical antibiotics have been started, but further testing is needed to determine the causative organism.
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's hypotension and low urine output can lead to further electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.
* Delirium/confusion: The patient's sedation and intubation can exacerbate her delirium and confusion, making it difficult to assess her mental status and potentially leading to further complications.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diarrhea and possible short gut syndrome can lead to malabsorption, electrolyte imbalances, and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's CAD and CHF can worsen, leading to further cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.

In conclusion, the patient is a high-risk individual with multiple comorbidities and complications. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and improve her outcome.

   80 F with CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD and multiple abdominal surgeries
   tranfer from OSH for 2nd opinion of diarrhea who is now admitted to
   MICU for hypoxia.
   .
   # Hypoxia Resp Failure: Patient was admitted with worsening hypoxia and
   CXR with central patchy infiltrates that could represent pulmonary
   edema vs underlying ILD. Patient has hx ILD but is not on home O2. This
   morning, she had a witnessed aspiration yesterday and then had a
   hypoxic event where she acutely desated and became unresponsive
   requiring emergent intubation. P/F ratio 177 and CXR with bilateral
   infiltrates and she was ventilated with ardsnet protocol.
   - Vent: continue to wean FiO2 and PEEP using ardsnet tidal volumes
   tolerating PaO2 70-80
   - continue d3 Vanc / d3 aztreonam for empriric coverage of HAP; d2 for
   flagyl for aspiration pna
   - echo today to eval EF
   - continue ipratropium q 6 and albuterol q4hrs PRN
   - will obtain CT chest / abdomen / pelvis today, consider bronchoscopy
   - acquire OSH CXR / CT chest imaging
   .
   # Leukocytosis: She had new leukocytosis yesterday, but today is
   trending down. Sputum with 1+ GPCs
   - f/u stool cx
   - UCx: pending
   - sputum cx: GPCs
   - legionella UA
   - check blood cx, although lower yield as will have already received
   abx
   - given respiratory failure, will give empric abx; Vanc and Aztreonam
   - IVF boluses PRN
   .
   # hx COPD, ? hx ILD: not on home O2.
   - repeat CT chest when able
   - cont Advair and Singulair
   .
   # Diarrhea: has had extensive w/u without diagnosis. Leading diagnosis
   is short gut ("short colon") although I beleive short colon does not
   typically cause diarrhea. Infections have been repeated r/o.
   Microscopic colitis is under consideration and biopsies are pending at
   OSH. Likewise labs for VIPoma, carcinoid syndrom and fat malabsorbtion
   are pending. Pancreatic insufficiency should also be considered.
   - cont Metamucil, nortriptyline
   - d/c immodium until stool cx neg
   - repeat C.diff, O/P, cryto/isosporidium
   - obtain stool na and K for stool osms -> stool currently not liquiid
   enough
   - f/u VIP, 5HIAA, fecal fat from OSH
   - colon biopsy on [**3-12**] at OSH still pending
   - consult GI today
   - CT chest / abdomen / pelvis
   .
   # Gastritis/ GERD:
   - cont PP IV, avoid PO PPI
   - d/c sucrulfate
   .
   # CAD: not on ASA? will need to ask pt when off BiPap
   -  cont plavix
   -  d/c simvastatin
   .
   # Hx Afib: in NSR now at HR 90. Last night had episode of afib with RVR
   - cont diltiazem 240mg [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH was 3.71 at OSH ahd Levothyroxine dose appears to
   have been decreased from 200mg to 100mg daily.
   # CODE: full, confirmed w son and patient

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old female admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, diarrhea, and atrial fibrillation. She has a complex medical history, including CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%. Her oxygen saturation is 94%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of 106 bpm. Her blood pressure is 120/53 mmHg.
* Hemodynamic: The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is 5 mmHg, and her cardiac index is 2.3 L/min/m2.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has diarrhea and is receiving treatment with metronidazole and loperamide. She is also receiving proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for gastritis.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine level is 0.9 mg/dL, and her urine output is 619 mL.
* Neurological: The patient is responsive to verbal commands and has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 13.

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to her underlying ILD and COPD, as well as her recent aspiration event.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely contributing to her respiratory failure and hypotension.
* Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is likely due to her respiratory failure and may be a sign of infection.
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder is likely due to her underlying medical conditions and may be contributing to her respiratory failure.
* Delirium and confusion: The patient's delirium and confusion are likely due to her underlying medical conditions and may be contributing to her respiratory failure.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Ventilatory support: The patient will continue to receive mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%.
* Antibiotics: The patient will receive empiric antibiotics for pneumonia, including vancomycin and aztreonam.
* Gastrointestinal support: The patient will receive treatment for diarrhea, including metronidazole and loperamide.
* Cardiovascular support: The patient will receive treatment for atrial fibrillation, including diltiazem and warfarin.
* Renal support: The patient will receive treatment for her renal failure, including furosemide and dopamine.

The patient's potential complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if her underlying medical conditions are not managed effectively.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen if her underlying medical conditions are not managed effectively.
* Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may worsen if her underlying medical conditions are not managed effectively.
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder may worsen if her underlying medical conditions are not managed effectively.
* Delirium and confusion: The patient's delirium and confusion may worsen if her underlying medical conditions are not managed effectively.

Summary:

The patient is a 80-year-old female with a history of CAD, CHF, CVA, ILD, COPD, and multiple abdominal surgeries, admitted to the MICU for hypoxia and respiratory failure. She has a witnessed aspiration event yesterday and had a hypoxic event, requiring emergent intubation. She has a P/F ratio of 177 and CXR with bilateral infiltrates, consistent with ARDS. She is currently on ventilator support with ARDSnet protocol.

The patient has a number of medical conditions, including:

* Respiratory failure
* Hypoxemia
* Leukocytosis
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder
* Delirium/confusion
* Atrial fibrillation (AFIB)
* Hypotension
* Diarrhea
* Gastritis/GERD
* CAD
* Hypothyroidism

The patient has undergone a number of tests and procedures, including:

* Transthoracic echo
* Blood cultures
* Sputum cultures
* CT chest/abdomen/pelvis
* Bronchoscopy
* Colon biopsy
* Stool cultures
* Blood tests, including CBC, electrolytes, and liver function tests

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: worsening hypoxia, increased risk of pneumonia
* Leukocytosis: increased risk of infection, sepsis
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder: worsening hypotension, cardiac arrhythmias
* Delirium/confusion: worsening cognitive function, increased risk of falls
* Atrial fibrillation: increased risk of stroke, cardiac arrhythmias
* Hypotension: worsening cardiac function, decreased perfusion to vital organs
* Diarrhea: worsening electrolyte imbalance, increased risk of dehydration
* Gastritis/GERD: worsening esophageal damage, increased risk of bleeding
* CAD: worsening cardiac function, increased risk of myocardial infarction
* Hypothyroidism: worsening cognitive function, increased risk of depression

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue to wean FiO2 and PEEP using ARDSnet tidal volumes
* Continue empiric coverage of HAP with d3 Vanc and d3 aztreonam
* Obtain CT chest/abdomen/pelvis and consider bronchoscopy
* Acquire OSH CXR/CT chest imaging
* Continue ipratropium q6 and albuterol q4hrs PRN
* F/u stool cx and UCx
* Check blood cx, although lower yield as will have already received abx
* Given respiratory failure, give empiric abx; Vanc and Aztreonam
* IVF boluses PRN
* Repeat CT chest when able
* Continue Advair and Singulair
* Cont Metamucil, nortriptyline
* D/c immodium until stool cx neg
* Repeat C.diff, O/P, cryto/isosporidium
* Obtain stool Na and K for stool osms
* F/u VIP, 5HIAA, fecal fat from OSH
* Colon biopsy on [**3-12**] at OSH still pending
* Consult GI today
* CT chest/abdomen/pelvis
